Her reflections were interrupted by the entrance of Lady Catherine, who, as soon as she had finished her cup of tea, began to inquire into the cause of their being all three together in the breakfast-room. Elizabeth, with a slight blush, expressed her intention of accepting Mr. Collins's offer, and her aunt's satisfaction was inexpressible. "Now, my dear," she cried, "I knew you would. Upon my word, I was almost angry that you delayed it so long. But you are come to your senses at last, and I am very glad of it. Now, my dear, you must not be foolish. You must not. You have only to think of what is proper for you. You must consult your own happiness. You consult it admirably in marrying Mr. Collins. You consult mine too, for I could not be easy while you remained single. But you must not be influenced by your silly sister. She is a conceited girl. She wishes to be distinguished for her wit and her desirableness. She is a romantic, absurd being. But you are a sensible girl. You know what is your interest, and you will do what is right. I am sure Mr. Collins is a most worthy young man. His income, I am told, is at least three thousand a year. Upon my word, my dear, you could not do better. You could not do half so well. You must not be led astray by young men with handsome faces, and nothing else. They are all vanity and conceit. Mr. Collins has not a handsomer face perhaps; but he has three thousand a year." Elizabeth listened to all this with a patience which surprised herself. She was too much amused to feel any resentment, and too little disposed to take her aunt's advice to attend to it. Lady Catherine, however, was not discouraged by any want of attention. She continued her discourse, and gave her all the benefit of her own great experience and judgment, till Elizabeth was forced to leave the room to laugh. Her aunt followed her, still talking, and entreating her to be serious, and not ruin herself and all her family by such a match. Elizabeth, however, was too well pleased with her own resolution to be shaken in it by any arguments, and though she listened to Lady Catherine with all the attention which her aunt's eagerness could demand, she resolved to adhere firmly to her first intention. Her father and the housekeeper entered the room while Lady Catherine was yet holding her by the arm, and entreating her to promise never to marry Mr. Collins. Elizabeth quietly disengaged herself, and her father, observing that his daughter looked somewhat discomposed, led her away to join the others in the shrubbery. "Well, Lizzy," said he, as soon as they were by themselves, "have you heard what your aunt has been wishing for?" "Yes, my dear father, I have heard it all. The consideration of Lydia's warmth, her childishness, her invincible ignorance, and want of discretion, as to the serious concerns of life, now struck her more forcibly. She was appalled at the idea of her being exposed to the arts and manoeuvres of so unprincipled a man. "And yet," thought she, "if I were to tell Papa, or Mama, or Kitty, or even Elizabeth, how could they believe it? It is too improbable." She wished she had some confidant, some good friend to whom she might apply for counsel; but alas! she had none. She was afraid to mention what she had heard to any one else in the family; and as to the inhabitants of Meryton, she had early learnt to despise them. In this perplexity, she recollected Colonel Forster. He was a sensible man, not inclined to suspect without reason, and withal a kind-hearted neighbour. "I will write to him," thought she; "he will advise me what to do." She immediately sat down, and in half an hour finished a letter, which she sealed with a trembling hand, and committed to the post. The idea of actually encountering Wickham, of being in the same house with him, seemed absolutely dreadful. She wished it was possible she might avoid seeing him at Pemberley; but the card of invitation was come, and must be answered. She wished she had rather declined accepting it; but the hope of seeing Jane, and of receiving some intelligence respecting her, was her constant consolation. She wished she could be strong enough to go through the visit without agitation, and convince herself of Lydia's being happy, though all her former opinions should be false. But this appeared a point beyond her strength. She felt that she should never see Wickham without horror. The conviction was becoming stronger within her every moment, that some dreadful event had happened, and that her sister, her youngest, best beloved sister, was beyond the reach of her affection and protection. She was miserable. She walked about in tears, regretting that she had ever read Miss Gardiner's letter, and wishing heartily she had been at home, to act in this trying affair with the advice of her family. Her mind was in a perfect tumult of anxiety and doubt. She wished it were morning, that she might send for Miss Gardiner, and consult with her; but it was past eleven, and she feared it would be midnight before she could receive an answer. At last, overcome by fatigue, she retired to her room, and endeavoured to seek repose; but it was long before sleep could close her eyes upon such sorrowful thoughts.
